statement.p: Consider the radioactive decay model for Iodine-123: \displaystyle{A}={16.6}{\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{t}}{{13.2}}}}
where \displaystyle{t} is in units of hours.
What is the annual percent increase or decrease?
Use 365 days/year, 8760 hours per year, and 525600 minutes per year.

solution.p: The initial amount is the coefficient in front, because when \displaystyle{t}={0} the second factor is just one. So the initial amount is 16.6.
To obtain the annual percent decrease, we need to convert the units to years. 13.2 hours is \displaystyle\frac{{13.2}}{{8760}}={0.0015068493150685} years.

Next we need to convert to the form \displaystyle{\left({1}+{p}\right)}^{{t}}. We can do this by expanding \displaystyle{\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{t}}{{0.0015068493150685}}}}={\left({\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{1}}{{0.0015068493150685}}}}\right)}^{{t}}={1.6809249833214}{E}-{200}^{{t}}. Now we can calculate the percent decrease as \displaystyle{1}-{1.6809249833214}{E}-{200}={1}. Converting to percent this is \displaystyle{100}{\left({1}\right)}={100}\%.
